items.title: I can recall the four common factors shared by all organisms
items.what: All cells contain four common features: genetic material, cytosol, ribosomes, and a plasma membrane. These are present in every living cell, from bacteria to human cells.
items.why: Recognising these universal features helps you identify cells and understand the minimum requirements for life to exist.
items.example: A bacterial cell and a human skin cell both contain DNA (genetic material), cytosol (the liquid inside), ribosomes (for making proteins), and a plasma membrane (the outer boundary).

subtopic.name: Living Things and Cell Theory
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental characteristics that define living organisms, the distinction between biotic and abiotic factors, and the cell theory that underpins all of biology.
subtopic.why: Understanding what makes something alive is essential for studying biology. Cell theory provides the foundation for understanding how all organisms function and reproduce.

items.title: I can define the terms biotic and abiotic
items.what: Biotic refers to living things made up of at least one cell. Abiotic refers to non-living things that are not made of cells.
items.why: Distinguishing between living and non-living factors is fundamental to understanding ecosystems and how organisms interact with their environment.
items.example: In a forest ecosystem, biotic factors include trees, fungi, and bacteria. Abiotic factors include sunlight, water, temperature, and rocks.

subtopic.name: Living Things and Cell Theory
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental characteristics that define living organisms, the distinction between biotic and abiotic factors, and the cell theory that underpins all of biology.
subtopic.why: Understanding what makes something alive is essential for studying biology. Cell theory provides the foundation for understanding how all organisms function and reproduce.

items.title: I can define the terms unicellular and multicellular
items.what: Unicellular organisms consist of only one cell, while multicellular organisms are made up of more than one cell working together.
items.why: Understanding cellular organisation helps explain the diversity of life, from single-celled bacteria to complex organisms like humans with trillions of cells.
items.example: The alga Caulerpa taxifolia is unicellular despite growing up to 3 metres long. A blue whale is multicellular, consisting of about 100 quadrillion cells.

subtopic.name: Living Things and Cell Theory
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental characteristics that define living organisms, the distinction between biotic and abiotic factors, and the cell theory that underpins all of biology.
subtopic.why: Understanding what makes something alive is essential for studying biology. Cell theory provides the foundation for understanding how all organisms function and reproduce.

items.title: I can outline the function of genetic material in cells
items.what: Genetic material (DNA) contains hereditary information and genes that code for proteins. It stores the instructions needed for cell function and reproduction.
items.why: Genetic material is what allows cells to reproduce and pass on traits to the next generation, making it essential for life to continue.
items.example: The DNA in a muscle cell contains the genes that code for proteins like actin and myosin, which allow the muscle to contract.

subtopic.name: Living Things and Cell Theory
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental characteristics that define living organisms, the distinction between biotic and abiotic factors, and the cell theory that underpins all of biology.
subtopic.why: Understanding what makes something alive is essential for studying biology. Cell theory provides the foundation for understanding how all organisms function and reproduce.

items.title: I can outline the functions of cytosol, ribosomes, and the plasma membrane
items.what: Cytosol is the liquid inside cells where many reactions occur. Ribosomes synthesise proteins. The plasma membrane separates the cell interior from the exterior and controls what enters and leaves.
items.why: Each of these components plays a critical role in cell survival. Without any one of them, the cell could not carry out essential life processes.
items.example: When a cell needs to make an enzyme, ribosomes in the cytosol read the genetic instructions and assemble amino acids into the protein, while the plasma membrane keeps the cell contents contained.

subtopic.name: Living Things and Cell Theory
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental characteristics that define living organisms, the distinction between biotic and abiotic factors, and the cell theory that underpins all of biology.
subtopic.why: Understanding what makes something alive is essential for studying biology. Cell theory provides the foundation for understanding how all organisms function and reproduce.

items.title: I can recall and explain the cell theory
items.what: Cell theory states that all living things are made up of at least one cell, cells are the basic unit of life, and all cells come from pre-existing cells.
items.why: Cell theory is one of the fundamental principles of biology that explains how life is organised and how new organisms arise.
items.example: When you cut your skin, new skin cells are produced by existing skin cells dividing. You cannot create a new cell from non-living matter.

subtopic.name: Living Things and Cell Theory
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental characteristics that define living organisms, the distinction between biotic and abiotic factors, and the cell theory that underpins all of biology.
subtopic.why: Understanding what makes something alive is essential for studying biology. Cell theory provides the foundation for understanding how all organisms function and reproduce.

items.title: I can define the term plasma membrane and explain its role
items.what: The plasma membrane is a semi-permeable membrane made of a phospholipid bilayer that separates the internal environment of a cell from its external environment.
items.why: Without a plasma membrane, a cell could not exist because it would have no boundary to contain its contents or control the exchange of substances.
items.example: The plasma membrane of a red blood cell allows oxygen to enter and carbon dioxide to leave, while keeping the cell's haemoglobin inside.

subtopic.name: Plasma Membrane Structure and Function
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure of the plasma membrane, including the phospholipid bilayer, proteins, carbohydrates, and cholesterol, as well as how these components work together to control cell function.
subtopic.why: The plasma membrane is essential for cell survival as it controls what enters and leaves the cell. Understanding its structure explains how cells communicate, recognise each other, and maintain their internal environment.

items.title: I can define the terms hydrophilic and hydrophobic
items.what: Hydrophilic means water-attracting or water-soluble. Hydrophobic means water-repelling or not water-soluble.
items.why: These properties determine how substances interact with the plasma membrane and whether they can cross it directly or need assistance from transport proteins.
items.example: The phosphate heads of phospholipids are hydrophilic and face the watery environments inside and outside the cell, while the fatty acid tails are hydrophobic and face inward, away from water.

subtopic.name: Plasma Membrane Structure and Function
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure of the plasma membrane, including the phospholipid bilayer, proteins, carbohydrates, and cholesterol, as well as how these components work together to control cell function.
subtopic.why: The plasma membrane is essential for cell survival as it controls what enters and leaves the cell. Understanding its structure explains how cells communicate, recognise each other, and maintain their internal environment.

items.title: I can explain the fluid mosaic model of the plasma membrane
items.what: The fluid mosaic model describes the plasma membrane as a combination of different types of molecules (mosaic) that can move around within the membrane (fluid).
items.why: This model explains how the membrane is both stable enough to maintain cell structure and flexible enough to allow transport and cell signalling.
items.example: Proteins in the plasma membrane can drift sideways through the phospholipid bilayer, allowing receptor proteins to cluster together when a hormone binds to the cell.

subtopic.name: Plasma Membrane Structure and Function
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure of the plasma membrane, including the phospholipid bilayer, proteins, carbohydrates, and cholesterol, as well as how these components work together to control cell function.
subtopic.why: The plasma membrane is essential for cell survival as it controls what enters and leaves the cell. Understanding its structure explains how cells communicate, recognise each other, and maintain their internal environment.

items.title: I can recall the four main components of the plasma membrane
items.what: The plasma membrane consists of phospholipids, proteins, carbohydrates, and cholesterol. Each component has a specific structure and function.
items.why: Knowing these components helps you understand how the membrane performs its various functions, from transport to cell recognition.
items.example: A diagram of a plasma membrane shows phospholipids forming the bilayer, proteins embedded within, carbohydrate chains attached to some molecules, and cholesterol scattered between phospholipids.

subtopic.name: Plasma Membrane Structure and Function
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure of the plasma membrane, including the phospholipid bilayer, proteins, carbohydrates, and cholesterol, as well as how these components work together to control cell function.
subtopic.why: The plasma membrane is essential for cell survival as it controls what enters and leaves the cell. Understanding its structure explains how cells communicate, recognise each other, and maintain their internal environment.

items.title: I can describe the function of each plasma membrane component
items.what: Phospholipids form the selective barrier. Proteins transport substances and enable signalling. Carbohydrates help with cell recognition and adhesion. Cholesterol provides stability without reducing fluidity.
items.why: Understanding each component's function explains how cells interact with their environment, communicate with other cells, and control their internal conditions.
items.example: Glycoproteins (proteins with carbohydrates attached) on immune cells help them recognise and bind to foreign cells like bacteria, triggering an immune response.

subtopic.name: Plasma Membrane Structure and Function
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure of the plasma membrane, including the phospholipid bilayer, proteins, carbohydrates, and cholesterol, as well as how these components work together to control cell function.
subtopic.why: The plasma membrane is essential for cell survival as it controls what enters and leaves the cell. Understanding its structure explains how cells communicate, recognise each other, and maintain their internal environment.

items.title: I can identify the different components in a plasma membrane diagram
items.what: When viewing a diagram, you should be able to identify phospholipids, transmembrane proteins, peripheral proteins, glycoproteins, glycolipids, and cholesterol.
items.why: Being able to identify membrane components in diagrams is essential for exam questions and for understanding how real membranes function.
items.example: In a membrane diagram, a glycoprotein is identified by a protein spanning the membrane with a carbohydrate chain attached on the outside, while a glycolipid has the carbohydrate attached to a phospholipid head.

subtopic.name: Plasma Membrane Structure and Function
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure of the plasma membrane, including the phospholipid bilayer, proteins, carbohydrates, and cholesterol, as well as how these components work together to control cell function.
subtopic.why: The plasma membrane is essential for cell survival as it controls what enters and leaves the cell. Understanding its structure explains how cells communicate, recognise each other, and maintain their internal environment.

items.title: I can draw a labelled plasma membrane showing all key components
items.what: A complete plasma membrane drawing includes the phospholipid bilayer with heads facing outward and tails facing inward, embedded proteins, carbohydrate chains, and cholesterol molecules.
items.why: Drawing the membrane reinforces your understanding of how the components are arranged and how they relate to each other structurally.
items.example: When drawing a phospholipid bilayer, the hydrophilic heads form two parallel lines with the hydrophobic tails facing each other in the middle, creating a sandwich-like structure.

subtopic.name: Plasma Membrane Structure and Function
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure of the plasma membrane, including the phospholipid bilayer, proteins, carbohydrates, and cholesterol, as well as how these components work together to control cell function.
subtopic.why: The plasma membrane is essential for cell survival as it controls what enters and leaves the cell. Understanding its structure explains how cells communicate, recognise each other, and maintain their internal environment.

items.title: I can explain how membrane fluidity is affected by fatty acid composition
items.what: Unsaturated fatty acids in phospholipid tails have double bonds that create kinks, preventing tight packing and increasing membrane fluidity. Saturated fatty acids pack tightly and decrease fluidity.
items.why: Membrane fluidity affects how well the membrane functions, including how easily substances can move across it and how proteins can move within it.
items.example: A membrane with more unsaturated fatty acids in cold temperatures remains fluid, while a membrane with mostly saturated fatty acids would become rigid and less functional.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure of the plasma membrane, including the phospholipid bilayer, proteins, carbohydrates, and cholesterol, as well as how these components work together to control cell function.
subtopic.why: The plasma membrane is essential for cell survival as it controls what enters and leaves the cell. Understanding its structure explains how cells communicate, recognise each other, and maintain their internal environment.

items.title: I can define the terms prokaryote and eukaryote
items.what: A prokaryote is a single-celled organism without membrane-bound organelles. A eukaryote is an organism whose cells contain membrane-bound organelles, and can be unicellular or multicellular.
items.why: This classification system organises all life on Earth and helps explain differences in cell complexity and function.
items.example: Bacteria are prokaryotes because they lack a nucleus and other membrane-bound organelles. Humans are eukaryotes because our cells contain a nucleus, mitochondria, and other organelles enclosed by membranes.

subtopic.name: Prokaryotes and Eukaryotes
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the classification of organisms into prokaryotes and eukaryotes based on their cellular structure, particularly the presence or absence of membrane-bound organelles.
subtopic.why: Understanding the distinction between prokaryotes and eukaryotes is fundamental to biology as it explains the diversity of life and how different organisms have evolved different cellular strategies.

items.title: I can define the term nucleoid
items.what: The nucleoid is an irregularly shaped area within a prokaryotic cell where the genetic material (DNA) is located. It is not enclosed by a membrane.
items.why: Understanding the nucleoid helps distinguish prokaryotes from eukaryotes, which have their DNA contained within a membrane-bound nucleus.
items.example: In a bacterial cell, the circular DNA chromosome floats in the nucleoid region of the cytoplasm, rather than being enclosed in a nucleus like in animal cells.

subtopic.name: Prokaryotes and Eukaryotes
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the classification of organisms into prokaryotes and eukaryotes based on their cellular structure, particularly the presence or absence of membrane-bound organelles.
subtopic.why: Understanding the distinction between prokaryotes and eukaryotes is fundamental to biology as it explains the diversity of life and how different organisms have evolved different cellular strategies.

items.title: I can outline the cellular features of prokaryotes
items.what: Prokaryotic cells have no membrane-bound organelles, contain ribosomes, have genetic material in a nucleoid region (usually circular DNA), may have plasmids, and have a plasma membrane surrounded by a cell wall.
items.why: Knowing prokaryotic features helps you identify these cells and understand how they function without the complex organelles found in eukaryotes.
items.example: A bacterium has a cell wall for protection, a plasma membrane, ribosomes for protein synthesis, circular DNA in the nucleoid, and may have flagella for movement and plasmids containing extra genes.

subtopic.name: Prokaryotes and Eukaryotes
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the classification of organisms into prokaryotes and eukaryotes based on their cellular structure, particularly the presence or absence of membrane-bound organelles.
subtopic.why: Understanding the distinction between prokaryotes and eukaryotes is fundamental to biology as it explains the diversity of life and how different organisms have evolved different cellular strategies.

items.title: I can outline the cellular features of eukaryotes
items.what: Eukaryotic cells contain membrane-bound organelles including a nucleus with linear DNA, ribosomes, and a plasma membrane. Some have cell walls (plants, fungi), and some have flagella or cilia for movement.
items.why: Understanding eukaryotic features explains how these more complex cells can perform specialised functions and form multicellular organisms.
items.example: A plant cell is eukaryotic because it has a nucleus containing linear chromosomes, chloroplasts for photosynthesis, mitochondria for respiration, and a cell wall for support.

subtopic.name: Prokaryotes and Eukaryotes
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the classification of organisms into prokaryotes and eukaryotes based on their cellular structure, particularly the presence or absence of membrane-bound organelles.
subtopic.why: Understanding the distinction between prokaryotes and eukaryotes is fundamental to biology as it explains the diversity of life and how different organisms have evolved different cellular strategies.

items.title: I can draw a labelled prokaryotic cell
items.what: A prokaryote diagram should include the plasma membrane, cell wall, nucleoid with circular DNA, ribosomes, cytosol, and may include plasmids, flagella, pili, and a capsule.
items.why: Being able to draw a prokaryote demonstrates understanding of its structure and helps in comparing it to eukaryotic cells.
items.example: When drawing a bacterium, start with an oval shape for the cell wall, add the plasma membrane inside it, show the nucleoid region with a circular DNA strand, scatter ribosomes throughout, and optionally add a flagellum for movement.

subtopic.name: Prokaryotes and Eukaryotes
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the classification of organisms into prokaryotes and eukaryotes based on their cellular structure, particularly the presence or absence of membrane-bound organelles.
subtopic.why: Understanding the distinction between prokaryotes and eukaryotes is fundamental to biology as it explains the diversity of life and how different organisms have evolved different cellular strategies.

items.title: I can identify whether a cell is prokaryotic or eukaryotic based on its features
items.what: The key distinguishing feature is the presence of membrane-bound organelles. If a cell has a nucleus or other membrane-bound organelles, it is eukaryotic. If it lacks these, it is prokaryotic.
items.why: This skill is essential for exam questions that show cell diagrams and ask you to classify the cell type with justification.
items.example: A paramecium is unicellular but is classified as a eukaryote (not a prokaryote) because it contains membrane-bound organelles including a nucleus, food vacuoles, and contractile vacuoles.

subtopic.name: Prokaryotes and Eukaryotes
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the classification of organisms into prokaryotes and eukaryotes based on their cellular structure, particularly the presence or absence of membrane-bound organelles.
subtopic.why: Understanding the distinction between prokaryotes and eukaryotes is fundamental to biology as it explains the diversity of life and how different organisms have evolved different cellular strategies.

items.title: I can identify which kingdoms are prokaryotic and which are eukaryotic
items.what: Prokaryotes include bacteria and archaea. Eukaryotes include protists, fungi, plants, and animals. Only fungi, plants, and animals are always multicellular.
items.why: Understanding how organisms are classified helps you predict cellular features and understand evolutionary relationships.
items.example: When asked which kingdoms contain organisms with membrane-bound organelles, the answer is protists, fungi, plants, and animals. Bacteria and archaea are prokaryotic and lack these organelles.

subtopic.name: Prokaryotes and Eukaryotes
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the classification of organisms into prokaryotes and eukaryotes based on their cellular structure, particularly the presence or absence of membrane-bound organelles.
subtopic.why: Understanding the distinction between prokaryotes and eukaryotes is fundamental to biology as it explains the diversity of life and how different organisms have evolved different cellular strategies.

items.title: I can describe what compartmentalisation means
items.what: Compartmentalisation refers to the division of a cell into separate membrane-bound compartments (organelles), each maintaining specific conditions for particular chemical reactions.
items.why: Compartmentalisation allows multiple different reactions to occur simultaneously without interfering with each other, making cells more efficient.
items.example: Without compartmentalisation, digestive enzymes from lysosomes would break down the cell's own proteins. By containing these enzymes within the lysosome membrane, the cell protects itself.

subtopic.name: Organelles and Compartmentalisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure and function of organelles found in plant and animal cells, the concept of compartmentalisation, and how cells are specialised for different functions.
subtopic.why: Organelles allow eukaryotic cells to perform complex chemical reactions efficiently by separating them into distinct compartments. Understanding organelles explains how cells carry out their specific functions.

items.title: I can explain the importance of compartmentalisation for cells
items.what: Compartmentalisation increases reaction efficiency by concentrating reactants in small spaces, allows incompatible reactions to occur in the same cell, and enables cells to maintain different conditions in different areas.
items.why: Eukaryotic cells are relatively large, making compartmentalisation necessary for chemical reactions to occur efficiently.
items.example: In a small organelle, reactant molecules are more likely to bump into each other and react than if they were spread throughout the entire cell. This is why mitochondria can efficiently produce ATP.

subtopic.name: Organelles and Compartmentalisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure and function of organelles found in plant and animal cells, the concept of compartmentalisation, and how cells are specialised for different functions.
subtopic.why: Organelles allow eukaryotic cells to perform complex chemical reactions efficiently by separating them into distinct compartments. Understanding organelles explains how cells carry out their specific functions.

items.title: I can identify and describe the function of the nucleus
items.what: The nucleus is a double-membrane-bound organelle containing genetic material (DNA). It stores and executes the genetic code, and DNA is passed to daughter cells during cell division.
items.why: The nucleus is often called the control centre of the cell because it contains the instructions for making all the proteins the cell needs.
items.example: When a cell needs to produce insulin, the instructions in the DNA within the nucleus are first copied into RNA, which then leaves through nuclear pores to reach ribosomes.

subtopic.name: Organelles and Compartmentalisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure and function of organelles found in plant and animal cells, the concept of compartmentalisation, and how cells are specialised for different functions.
subtopic.why: Organelles allow eukaryotic cells to perform complex chemical reactions efficiently by separating them into distinct compartments. Understanding organelles explains how cells carry out their specific functions.

items.title: I can identify and describe the functions of the endoplasmic reticulum
items.what: Rough endoplasmic reticulum has ribosomes attached and transports proteins to the Golgi apparatus. Smooth endoplasmic reticulum lacks ribosomes and synthesises and transports lipids.
items.why: The ER is essential for producing and transporting materials needed by the cell and for export from the cell.
items.example: In a cell producing digestive enzymes, ribosomes on the rough ER make the enzyme proteins, which are then packaged into vesicles and sent to the Golgi apparatus for processing.

subtopic.name: Organelles and Compartmentalisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure and function of organelles found in plant and animal cells, the concept of compartmentalisation, and how cells are specialised for different functions.
subtopic.why: Organelles allow eukaryotic cells to perform complex chemical reactions efficiently by separating them into distinct compartments. Understanding organelles explains how cells carry out their specific functions.

items.title: I can identify and describe the functions of the Golgi apparatus, vesicles, and lysosomes
items.what: The Golgi apparatus modifies and packages proteins into vesicles. Vesicles transport materials within the cell and to the plasma membrane. Lysosomes contain enzymes that break down waste materials and foreign matter.
items.why: These organelles work together to process, transport, and recycle materials, keeping the cell functioning properly.
items.example: A protein made for export is packaged by the Golgi into a vesicle, which moves to the plasma membrane and releases the protein outside the cell through exocytosis.

subtopic.name: Organelles and Compartmentalisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure and function of organelles found in plant and animal cells, the concept of compartmentalisation, and how cells are specialised for different functions.
subtopic.why: Organelles allow eukaryotic cells to perform complex chemical reactions efficiently by separating them into distinct compartments. Understanding organelles explains how cells carry out their specific functions.

items.title: I can identify and describe the function of mitochondria
items.what: Mitochondria are double-membrane organelles where stages of aerobic cellular respiration occur, releasing usable energy in the form of ATP. They have their own DNA and ribosomes.
items.why: Mitochondria provide the energy currency (ATP) that powers nearly all cellular activities, making them essential for cell survival.
items.example: Sperm cells contain many mitochondria because they need large amounts of ATP energy to power the flagellum that propels them towards the egg.

subtopic.name: Organelles and Compartmentalisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure and function of organelles found in plant and animal cells, the concept of compartmentalisation, and how cells are specialised for different functions.
subtopic.why: Organelles allow eukaryotic cells to perform complex chemical reactions efficiently by separating them into distinct compartments. Understanding organelles explains how cells carry out their specific functions.

items.title: I can identify and describe the function of chloroplasts
items.what: Chloroplasts are double-membrane organelles found in plant cells where photosynthesis occurs. They contain chlorophyll in stacks called grana and convert light energy into glucose.
items.why: Chloroplasts allow plants to produce their own food from sunlight, carbon dioxide, and water, making them the basis of most food chains.
items.example: Leaf cells contain many chloroplasts to maximise photosynthesis, while root cells have no chloroplasts because they are underground and receive no light.

subtopic.name: Organelles and Compartmentalisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure and function of organelles found in plant and animal cells, the concept of compartmentalisation, and how cells are specialised for different functions.
subtopic.why: Organelles allow eukaryotic cells to perform complex chemical reactions efficiently by separating them into distinct compartments. Understanding organelles explains how cells carry out their specific functions.

items.title: I can compare the structures of plant and animal cells
items.what: Both plant and animal cells have a nucleus, mitochondria, ribosomes, ER, Golgi apparatus, and plasma membrane. Plant cells also have a cell wall, large permanent vacuole, and chloroplasts, which animal cells lack.
items.why: Understanding these differences explains why plants can photosynthesise and maintain rigid structures while animals cannot.
items.example: A plant cell has a cell wall for structural support (animals use bones or exoskeletons instead), a large vacuole for water storage and turgor pressure, and chloroplasts for photosynthesis.

subtopic.name: Organelles and Compartmentalisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure and function of organelles found in plant and animal cells, the concept of compartmentalisation, and how cells are specialised for different functions.
subtopic.why: Organelles allow eukaryotic cells to perform complex chemical reactions efficiently by separating them into distinct compartments. Understanding organelles explains how cells carry out their specific functions.

items.title: I can draw labelled plant and animal cells
items.what: An animal cell drawing should include the nucleus, mitochondria, ribosomes, rough and smooth ER, Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, vesicles, and plasma membrane. A plant cell includes these plus a cell wall, large vacuole, and chloroplasts.
items.why: Drawing cells reinforces understanding of organelle location and the differences between cell types.
items.example: When drawing a plant cell, place the large central vacuole taking up most of the cell space, with chloroplasts and other organelles around the edges near the plasma membrane and cell wall.

subtopic.name: Organelles and Compartmentalisation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the structure and function of organelles found in plant and animal cells, the concept of compartmentalisation, and how cells are specialised for different functions.
subtopic.why: Organelles allow eukaryotic cells to perform complex chemical reactions efficiently by separating them into distinct compartments. Understanding organelles explains how cells carry out their specific functions.

items.title: I can explain which organelles would be present in specialised cells
items.what: Specialised cells have more of certain organelles based on their function. Cells needing energy have many mitochondria. Cells producing proteins have extensive rough ER and Golgi apparatus.
items.why: Understanding this relationship between organelle numbers and cell function helps predict cell structure from function and vice versa.
items.example: Stomach lining cells that secrete digestive enzymes have many ribosomes, extensive rough ER, and large Golgi apparatus to produce and export these protein enzymes.
